title: Tarka Dal

ingredients.content: 700 g water, plus extra for soaking
15 g fresh root ginger, peeled, cut in round slices (2 mm)
1 - 2 fresh green chillies, halved, deseeded, to taste
1 tsp fine sea salt, or to taste
1 small handful fresh coriander leaves, chopped, for garnish (approx. 5 g)

preparations.content: Soak mung dal for at least 8 hours or overnight in plenty of water. Rinse well then drain.

Place soaked and drained mung dal, water and 2 finely sliced garlic cloves in mixing bowl. Replace measuring cup with simmering basket, then boil <b>8 min/100°C//speed <b>. Skim froth from surface and discard.
Add oil then, replace measuring cup with simmering basket, and simmer <b>25 min/98°C//speed <b>. Transfer to a bowl (do not drain) and keep warm. Clean and dry mixing bowl.
Place cumin seeds in mixing bowl and toast <b>5 min/Varoma/speed <b>.
Add ghee, onions, ginger and chillies then chop <b>5 sec/speed 5<b>. Scrape down sides of mixing bowl with spatula then sauté <b>5 min/120°C/speed 0.5<b>.
Add remaining 4 finely sliced garlic cloves, turmeric, garam masala and salt then cook <b>5 min/100°C/speed 0.5<b>.
Add reserved cooked lentil mixture and stir <b>30 sec//speed 2.5<b>. Stir in chopped coriander leaves just before serving.

hintsAndTricks: If the mixture boils up onto the mixing bowl lid then reduce the cooking temperature to 95°C for 2 minutes before turning up to 98°C again in step 3.
For a quicker version, use red split lentils which require no soaking.

‘Tarka’ here refers to the method where spices and chillies are fried and added to the dish at the end of cooking. Like many spiced dishes, you may find this tastes better reheated the day after it’s been prepared, when the flavours have had more time to develop. It is a great, economical accompaniment to dry curries and rice to complete a meal. Dal is eaten very widely in India and is a good source of protein.
